39448133.review:
IF YOU SSMMMMMEEEELLLLLLL.... WHAT THE ROCK FROM THE STEAMWORKSHOP IS COOKING!!! 

I have been playing wrestling games since the 90's. My absolute favorites were WCW VS NWO Revenge and WWF No Mercy. Those were the two games that really set a new standard for wrestling games with a simplistic approach that would keep both n00bs and veterans happy. Fire Pro Wrestling World is definitely not on the caliber of WWF No Mercy, but can still provide some serious fun for gamers of all skills. I will warn you, it took me a bit to get into this game. I didn't find the mechanics appealing at first, but once I got the drift of how the game operated I really started to enjoy the gaming experience.

The [b]gameplay[/b] will either appeal to you or appall you. As I said I had a problem getting into it at first, but it wasn't until I understood the mechanics that I started appreciating the game. The mission mode in-game definitely helped me become familiar with the mechanics. Once you understand the mechanics, the game comes together quite nicely. Some of the game modes include exhibition, tournament, league, and battle royal. There are cage match and hardcore match options to add a little flavor to the game. If you do hit characters hard or frequent enough, they will start bleeding. Other game modes include barbed wire matches, tornado matches, and land-mine matches. My only major complaint is the hit box system. When you play the game for a while, you'll understand how it works. When you first start, you'll wonder why the heck it's so hard to hit another wrestler or lock-up in a grapple. Don't be surprised if you find yourself circling around an opponent for some time. Besides this, the game is pretty solid. I would recommend that devs consider fixing this issue in the future. It is possible to knock out the ref as well, but again, the way the hit boxes are set-up make it near impossible. This is especially true when you try to swing chairs or weapons in your opponent’s direction. There are still times where my friend and I look like were fanning one another instead of wrestling. A concept some may or may not like is the grappling. Grappling happens automatically; when two wrestlers are in close proximity, they automatically lock-up. You get used to it, but it can drive you nuts sometimes when the opponent is always trying to stand next to you to grapple. 

The [b]visuals [/b] themselves are decent. I won’t say bad as there is attention to detail, but they definitely are not over-the-top amazing. I would say they are comparable to Super Nintendo graphics, plus or minus a few special effects that the SNES couldn’t do. I think a little more could have been added to the visual realm in terms of damage on the wrestlers and damage around the ring. The [b]sounds[/b] are good – again nothing too amazing or really bad. The soundtrack can become repetitive after playing for a few hours. It would be nice to see (rather hear) some new tracks added to the list. There are no real promos where wrestlers talk, but there are certain moves in which wrestlers do make a sound. There is also no commentary in game (so don’t expect the quality of commentary Jim Ross brings or the randomness of Jerry “The King” Lawler). I should also mention the wrestler creation system is absolutely awesome. There is a lot of attention to detail from moves to stances. I am actually amazed at the amount of steam workshop content there is for this game. If you really love old school wrestlers, wrestlers from Japan or the current WWE line-up, you’ll definitely find a character that suits your style. If you want to get a little whacky, characters like Bas Rutten, Mirko “Cro Cop” Filipovic and even Cell from Dragon Ball Z are available. 

Overall, the game is pretty good for what it is. The price is quite steep in my opinion and I would highly recommend waiting for a sale. The game can become addicting quite quickly, but can really pee you off just as fast if you can’t get your grapple timing right. I’ve noticed online the slightest lag can definitely throw off your timing, so it’s a matter of practice to predict the right time in player verse player matches. I hope future updates address online multiplayer issues. Online numbers are quite low, but more importantly when you do start playing with a friend, you can only play against them. There isn’t really an option to play online against AI. The user interface is also a little confusing (maybe due to translations?) so sometimes it is a little difficult to get the exact match you want. Have fun Google-ing what some of it means!

RATING : 7.45/10

39265704.review:
I have nearly 600 hours invested into this game, and over 2 decades of the Fire Pro Wrestling series under my belt, going back to the release of 6-Man Scramble going back to the Sega Saturn. I've had every installment for every gaming console & handheld, and must say, this is the best one yet.

I have nearly 1000 wrestlers (all based on their real-life counterparts, even the referees) and have been simulating a very in-depth league (and have been doing leagues since 6-Man Scramble) using spreadsheets with ranking systems while running House Shows and Pay Per View events following New Japan Pro Wrestling & World Wonder Ring Stardom's real life schedule (my Women's Division has about 300 competitors in it.)

This game is not like the 2K games or the old Super Nintendo games. It's not about button mashing but precise timing. There's no idiotic gimmick matches, just FMW-based deathmatches. There's 10 CPU skill levels and many speed levels for those who want everything fast and turbo-based. 

The levels of the CAW system is where Fire Pro World, like every other installment, really shines. Every move, every grunt, every decal on a wrestler you can customize and choose. Want a power wrestler full of powerbombs, harsh clotheslines, and nasty suplexes? Or a flippy Mexican luchadore? Want to a make an Io Shirai, a Kairi Hojo or a Kana (Asuka)?

Create your wrestler's brain from the ground up assigning percentages to make them go for the right move at the precise time to either finish your opponent, or turn the tide in a hard fought match. MMA, deathmatches, battle royals, singles, tag, 6 man & 8=man tags..there's so much to do in this game and even if you just decide to simulate matches (where this game really shines) you'll never be disappointed. And you never know when that "CRITICAL" is going to pop up!

Run an E-Fed with the most in-depth, best wrestling game ever in the best wrestling game series ever. WIth the upcoming "Management of the Ring" Mode (think of it like a 2K Games GM Mode) and the official New Japan Pro Wrestling DLC with wrestlers like Kenny Omega, Kazuchika Okada & Hiroshi Tanahashi (amongst many others) re-create some amazing moments from past Wrestle Kingdom (NJPW's version of WrestleMania) events.

This is a wrestling game for the true hardcore wrestling fan and it will be the best squared-circle game you'll ever purchase. I guarantee it!

39140592.review:
The greatest wrestling game of all time? I'm not sure yet but it's definitely up there.

I grew up playing the N64 classics like WCW vs. NWO, Wrestlemania 2000, and No Mercy. Until I bought FPWW, I was 100% certain that WWF No Mercy would always be the greatest wrestling game of all time. But after a few hours with FPWW, it's becoming clear that No Mercy may have some legitimate competition.

A few caveats: FPWW doesn't have the polish of a licensed WWE title. There aren't any custscenes or voice overs or story mode. This game is just meat and potatoes wrestling. Furthermore, it's not an easy game to get into. The MASSIVE amount of customization options and move combinations is daunting at first. And the UI isn't exactly easy to use. It WILL take some time to warm up to it. But do yourself a favor and play the tutorial. Things will become clearer after a few missions.

Once you've warmed up a bit, go to the Steam Workshop and download some of your favorite wrestlers, rings, referees, etc. Then create wrestling stables for your favorite promotions. Now you're ready to recreate your favorite wrestling matches from yesteryear.

And that's what's so great about this game. The huge number of options makes it possible to recreate just about every wrestler and every wrestling match that's ever happened throughout history. For me, there's not much better than Stone Cold vs. The Rock on Monday Night Raw, or Shawn Michaels vs. The Undertaker in a steel cage.

The controls are deceptively simple, and feature a grapple system that will feel familiar to any fan of the N64 games. The "deceptive" part comes in with just how many move combinations there are. At its heart, there are small, medium, and big attacks. But there are strikes, grapples, running attacks, ground attacks, top rope maneuvers, counters, double team moves you can do with your tag partner, etc. etc. If you can think of it, it's probably in this game.

If you are currently or have ever been a wrestling fan and you love a good wrestling game, FPWW will not dissapoint.

39055064.review:
A cult classic revitalized for the modern age. There has been an active creative community around this series of games from the earliest days of the Web.  Bringing that community to Steam is an excellent modern touch. I don't have to spend hours copying CAW instructions anymore, I can simply subscribe to entire collections of well-made edits.

While I love having this series available again, there are some legitimate issues. [list]
[*] The UI is fairly clunky and could use some serious work. The menus can be confusing, and navigation is unwieldy. Even as an experienced player I had to research tutorials to figure out how to access downloaded wrestlers and rings. 
[*] The standalone game lacks some standard features previous games in the series included, especially story mode. There are understandable reasons for this and it is coming as DLC, but it is still a net negative.
[*] The game overall doesn't feel as refined as previous versions. 
[*] Controls are not as configurable as they should be. I primarily play this on a PC-powered arcade cabinet, but that is frustrated by the inability to remap some buttons.  It is also hindered because for some reason I can't switch between which controller I want to use.  This is an admittedly rare use-case but still frustrating.
[*] The game play retains the classic Fire Pro feeling. This is a good thing. However, the series has not kept up with modern competitors. The developers have not added things like apron spots (moves onto apron or off of apron), weapon interaction, or table spots. All of these things are in other games, and they could have been implemented within the framework of Fire Pro, but they weren't.
[*] This game mostly recycles previous Fire Pro games. Other than Workshop interaction (which is amazing), it doesn't feel like the series has really evolved.[/list] 

I still love the game and happily recommend it. But I can't help but feel like there were a lot of missed opportunities to grow and evolve the series.

38996834.review:
A lot of the negative reviews on here are unfair assessments of what is a highly enjoyable game with potential to grow.

1.) The people complaining about this game are just bad at it or haven't taken the time to learn how the game plays. This game is not a button masher. This game is about timing and planning your moves. Each match plays like a real wrestling match with stamina involved. Don't play like an idiot and you'll probably do okay once you learn the timing and buttons.

2.) You can't expect this game to be like WWF No Mercy if you looked at the screenshots before purchasing it. 

3.) This game is very fun, and at about 10 hours in - I am getting better. If I keep getting better, I will increase the difficulty and laugh at all of the whiners on here who are complaining about the controls or how the game is "too difficult."

4.) Lots of room for customization - this is a plus.

5.) The developers have promised updates - this is a plus.

6.) I got the game as a gift and I happily would have paid for it.

7.) Anyone calling this a bad game is just bad at this game or unwilling to learn how to play it.

38754935.review:
Ich würde dem "Spiel" wirklich gerne eine Kaufempfehlung geben, aber dafür reicht es meiner Meinung nach nur eingeschränkt. Wenn man sich über Fire Pro schlau macht heißt es eigentlich immer, es wäre besser als alle anderen, spielerisch und vor allem von der KI her, die die Wrestler so agieren lassen soll, wie sie es auch in Wirklichkeit machen würden. Das hier der größte Teil der Nutzer aber das Teil nur zum Simulieren von Matches verwendet sollte man vorher auch unbedingt wissen.
Ich habe mir diverse Wrestler mit Movesets und Logik heruntergeladen und diese gegeneinander antreten lassen. Die Matches sehen aber auch hier im Prinzip immer gleich aus. Am Anfang werden leichte Schläge, Tritte und Würfe ausgeteilt, danach nimmt die Intensität zu, was schwerere/stärkere Angriffe zur Folge hat und irgendwann dann das Matchende zur Folge hat. Ich schaue WWE, TNA und ganz selten mal ROH. Keines meiner bisher ca. 20 simulierten Matches ähnelte auch nur Ansatzweise einem Match, dass man so auch im TV sehen würde. Währends es bei den grossen Promotions Phasen gibt, in denen mal der eine, dann der andere Wrestler dominiert, wechselt bei Fire Pro diese Dominanz fast nach jedem Move. Es gibt also keine Phasen, in denen ein Wrestler 3-4 Minuten einsteckt, nur um dann mit einem Comeback doch noch den Sieg zu erringen. Über Fire Pro wird immer gesagt, die simulierten Matches wären realistischer als alles andere, ich kann dem ehrlich nicht zustimmen. Die Wrestler berechnen einfach aufgrund ihrer ihnen gegebene Logik, was sie in jeder Situation machen würden. Hier fehlt der Plan hinter dem Ganzen. Ein Wrestler denkt immer nur zwischen den Moves, hat aber kein langfristiges Ziel vor Auge. Ein Heel könnte nach dem dritten 2.9 Count auch einfach mal ausrasten und dann auf den Sieg pfeiffen, dafür dem anderen aber zeigen, wo der Frosch die Locken hat. Was ich auch des öfteren gelesen habe, dass die Wrestler bei Fire Pro eine Geschichte ohne Worte erzählen. Das ist vielleicht Wunschdenken, aber nachdem nach jedem Move wieder offen ist, wer gerade die Oberhand hat, ist das mehr als übertrieben. Festellen musste ich auch, dass egal ob ich einen Wrestler als Heel oder Babyface einsortierte, wird er fast immer ausgebuht.
Versteht mich jetzt nicht falsch, die Matches sind trotzdem sehr schön anzusehen und man freut sich, wenn sein eigener Wrestler so agiert, wie man es vorausgesehen hat, aber es ist eben nicht das, was man vielleicht erwartet. Wenn man dann damit anfängt sich in dem Spiel, oder besser der Simulation, etwas aufzubauen, wie eine eigene Promotion, dann trifft man sehr schnell auf die Grenzen. Lässt sich der Ring noch sehr schön selbst gestalten, hört es bei der Arena schon wieder auf. Wieso kann ich nicht grundlegende Farben definieren oder auch die Bannerwerbung ändern? Ich verstehe auch nicht, wieso ich beim Ring eigene Grafiken verwenden kann, aber nicht bei den Championgürteln! Die Auswahl an Titeln ist echt lächerlich und hat auch so gut wie keine Auswirkung auf das Spiel. Die Wrestler kommen grundsätzlich ohne Gürtel zum Ring. Angeblich wäre das nicht anders machbar, aber wenn ich mir die Charaktererstellung anschaue, dann müsste es nur einen weiteren "versteckten" Layer geben, wo eben der Gürtel beim Einmarsch sichtbar wäre, oder eben ein komplettes neues Attire nur für die Einmärsche. Also von wegen wäre nicht möglich ist mir hier einfach zu lächerlich. Bei den Titeln muss man auch vorher festlegen, bei welcher Matchart sie gewonnen werden können, das ist ja auch absolut realitätsfremd und jeder Booker würde wahrscheinlich hier seinem Albtraum gegenüberstehen. Eine Entscheidung, die ich einfach nicht nachvollziehen kann.
Die Matcharten sind sage ich mal in den 80er/90er Jahren hängen geblieben. Es gibt die normalen Matches, Käfig Matches und dann wird es leider schon wieder absurd mit Landmine Deathmatches  z.B. laut ingame Beschreibung liegen Mienen überall rum, tatsächlich sind ausserhalb des Rings und in den Ringecken Tische mit Stacheldraht. Battle Royal gesellt sich auch zu den Matches, leider auf 8 Teilnehmer beschränkt. Wer also einen 30 Mann Royal Rumble simulieren will bekommt hier gleich zwei Probleme. Neben dem schon erwähnten Limit von 8 Teilnehmern (in einer Liga kann ich doch auch mehr Wrestler auswählen!!!) kommt noch dazu, dass die Teilnehmer sich lieber pinnen als rauswerfen, da man den Pin nicht deaktivieren kann und somit immer beides zulässig ist.
Als Wrestling Fan macht es mir einerseits Spaß, Matches zu simulieren, allerdings möchte ich dann andererseits auch mehr. Ich will die Wrestler auch Promos machen lassen, Interviews führen, Storylines und Fehden ermöglichen. Als reiner Simulator für Standardmatches ist Fire Pro ganz lustig, aber dadurch, dass das ganze Drumherum einfach fehlt, bzw. sehr fragwürdig umgesetzt (Titel/Gürtel) wurde kann es auch nicht mehr sein, obwohl so viel Potenzial vorhanden ist. Auf der einen Seite sagt Fire Pro "mach was du willst!" und auf der anderen "nee, das System dafür hätten wir zwar, aber nein das darfst du nicht!".

Gerne wird Fire Pro auch immer in einem Atemzug mit WWE 2KXX genannt und was es doch alles besser macht. Sollte ich Bock auf eine eigene Promotion haben, dann kann ich bei den 2K Spielen um einiges mehr anstellen. Ich kann Arenen, Ringe, Gürtel und was weiß ich nicht alles erstellen. Ich kann Zwischensequenzen arrangieren, die Leute miteinander Fehden lassen. Ich kann Tag Teams entstehen und auch wieder zerbrechen lassen, wie ich will. Das Ganze dann noch in einer Promotion mit eigener Historie (Win/Losses/Titel) führen. "Ja, aber die Matches bei Fire Pro sind viel besser, wegen Logik und so!" Das mag sein, aber die obligatorischen Fehlgriffe und Tritte/Schläge ins Leere gibt es da genauso.
Dies ist mein erstes Fire Pro, ich bereue den Kauf nicht, es ist ja auch nicht sonderlich teuer, aber ganz ehrlich, hier fehlt so vieles und alles wirkt unüberlegt. Wäre das ein Early Access Ok, aber so doch nicht.

Fazit: Ordentliche Simulation, dank der Community mit denkbar jedem Wrestler den es jemals gab, langfristige Unterhaltung aber aufgrund der Limitierungen nicht gegeben, es sei denn man simuliert die selben wenigen Matchtypen immer und immer wieder. Spielen braucht man das Teil nicht, es gibt keinen Story- oder Karrieremodus. Wer also auf Matchvielfalt verzichten kann und wirklich nur Matches durchsimulieren will, der ist hier gut aufgehoben. Jeder der etwas mehr will muss sich gedulden, bis die DLCs das ganze vielleicht in etwas Brauchbares verwandeln. Das Potenzial ist auf jeden Fall da!

38707907.review:
So this game is. A lot.

For a while I was putting off writing this, as for hte most part I played Fire Pro Wrestling the same way most others here did: As a simulator. I downloaded a bunch of real life guys, made a dumb little tournament, and then ran my own promtion. And for a while, it was fun; Kevin Owens and Rick Rude had a halatious matchup. But I realized that this way, I was simply playing a 20 buck fantasy booker, and I wanted to try playing it on my own. So I made a character and went through the tutorials, and here's what I learned.

The gamedoes not play like any other wrestling game I've tried; lockups are automatic and the natural state. While strikes are possible, I've never seen one done well. As such, pretty much everything is a lockup. Even things like chops and punches are done in lockups. It seems that the best way to win a lockup is just pure speed; press one of the buttons and a direction as fast as possible and you get it done. The general idea is to follow the flow of an All Japan style match; smaller moves like takeovers and headlocks leading into your big flashy moves near the end. While this works in theory, I've also done entire matches without using the small moves, going exclusively for big stuff. There isn't too much of a penalty for it anyway. 

Character creation is the star of the show. While the main combat engine is fun, it's shocking just how well someone with a good sense of faces can turn even the admitatedly low definition characters adn sprites into something awesome. And the creator is "fun" in the sense that there are lots of parts to use and it's in theory easy to use them. It's a layer based sectional system; you work on one arm, then the other arm, and all of them are seperate parts rather than one cohesive body. Color seems to be an issue; I'd love a way to simply apply one base color and pattern across a body so I don't have to get the exact same color code eveyr time, but it's otherwise cool. 

The real big problme is navigating all this. The menu looks and feels like a game from the PS2; the background image is just a static ring and the way they are navigated just looks ugly, especially in tournament setups. I've also been having trouble connecting to opponents online and getting rid of characters from the workshop; even after unsubscribing they are still there, taking up space and making the game load slower.

- Bush

Fire Pro Wrestling World to put it succinctly is 'Better than the rest.'

The Fire Pro Wrestling series found its beginning back in 1989, the brainchild of Japanese programmer Masato Masuda who had already made waves in the video game industry programming the critical and commercial success 'Pro Wrestling' on the Nintendo Entertainment System. A much beloved title for oldschool gamers and wrestling fans alike.

When Fire Pro Wrestling made its debut on the market, no one would have any idea of the significance the series would have over an entire genre of games and yet remain completely niche and almost unknown to all but the most dedicated western audiences.
In truth, Fire Pro Wrestling is the father of modern wrestling games, innovating and refining many of the features we see in the games today.

To fully grasp the impact the Fire Pro Wrestling series has had over the wrestling game genre, we have to look at how two completely different cultures view Professional Wrestling in its entirety. While Pro Wrestling in the West has relied heavily on pageantry and characters to get over; Japanese wrestling is viewed as a legitimate sport, covered by the press and sports media. The ring drama does not unfold over a microphone or through awkward skits, but rather in-ring storytelling and match psychology.

This is where the fundamental difference between Western and Japanese developers have differed over the years in the wrestling game content they produce.
Western wrestling games have always relied heavily upon licenses and a particular brand to sell units. It never really mattered if the games were actually any good. Button mashing an opponents lifebar into oblivion while manipulating the cardboard cut out likeness of a real superstar has been the bread and butter staple of western wrestling games for decades. We loved it, and we continued to buy each installment of each licensed game, but ultimately were left with shallow gameplay and a complete lack of in-ring drama from developers who either didn't care or didn't understand pro wrestling, and some would argue, still don't.

Then along came the Fire Pro series. Through its early installments it began to build upon certain gameplay fundamentals. Unlicensed and unbranded, the series crammed the rosters with the likenesses of real wrestler and real promotions and focused solely on developing gameplay as the foundation the series would build upon through each installment.

Gameplay and customization is unequivocally the flame that has sustained the Fire Pro series from 1989 to 2017.
Giving players the tools not to beat a lifebar out of an opponent and slap on a guarunteed pinfall, but to actually tell their own stories with their own characters through their own preferred style of grappling.

The Fire Pro series was the first series to personalize its rosters with their own statistical parameters, utilize a customizable logic system and incorporate what we now consider basic features in a wrestling game such as stamina, fatigue and limb damage. Now Spike-Chunsoft have given the fans a new toybox to create in, and plan to throw in plenty of additional features as time progresses. With additional logo and ring editors entire promotions will rise and fall within the community and thousands of real and fictional wrestlers, grapplers and even MMA fighters will thrive and compete.

One of the staples of the Fire Pro series has been its minimalist presentation. The 2d graphics, simple introductions and focus on in ring action over amateur theatrics; while not necessarily appealing to the younger gamers of today, still remain colorful and beautifully hand animated. Many long time fans of the series also believe the 2d base allows for far more creative freedom in the editing process as well.

And creative freedom is what Fire Pro is all about. Molding your own unique vision, limited only by your imagination and not the lame narrative of some stooge writer. Fire Pro has a soul and is developed as a labor of love for fans, by fans, and is not just the annual mediocre churnout of a corporate brand.

The series isn't for everyone, but does boast an insanely hardcore following that even includes some of the wrestlers whose Fire Pro counterparts have appeared throughout the storied series. Some people are perfectly content with the offerings of the licensed brands; but those who love the Fire Pro series love it a lot and we owe a huge debt of gratitude to Tomoyuki Matsumoto, Tomozou Kantaku and all the developers at Spike-Chunsoft who have made this labor of love a reality at long last. With a PS4 console release on the way, it is safe to say many of us will be running across eachother on both platforms.

My Personal Fire Pro Wrestling history includes:

Fire Pro Wrestling G
Fire Pro Wrestlng D
Fire Pro Wrestling Z
Fire Pro Wrestling Returns (Japanese Edition)
Fire Pro Wrestling Returns (Agetec Edition)
Fire Pro Wrestling World (PC)

and eventually,

Fire Pro Wrestling World (PS4)

38426921.review:
This was the wrestling game I've been waiting for. It accomplishes a rare trick- it's fast and easy to get started in, yet it's also a better wrestling sim than the WWE games have ever managed, somehow capturing the feel of a scripted sport in an open format. Matches go back and forth and have dramatic reversals which leave the crowd gasping, different wrestlers play differently thanks to variable AI, and you can feel tension building. It's honestly fun to just watch the AI go at it, and setting up your own federation and seeing who wins in dream matches is a joy. 

Customization is, given the simplicity of the graphics, kind of entirely absurd. Playing with the various layers of attires can create some brilliant combinations, it's easy to import your own .wav entrance themes, and monkeying with movesets and AI can get you just about any concept you can envision. 

Presentation wise it could still use a little finessing- the Mission Mode is really essential to learning how to play the game yourself, and there's a lot the game itself could explain instead of leaving to the manual. The graphics do occasionally show the odd bit of clipping (which is weird for 2-D) though nothing that obstructs gameplay. And to be sure there are a few things the game can't do yet- ladder matches, table matches, and huge 30-man royal rumbles and the like. 

But overall, in terms of capturing the wrestling experience, this does better than anything I've ever seen. It's an easy recommend to any wrestling fan, and even if you're not, the fun of creating weird characters and making them fight in barbed wire deathmatches is hard to overstate. Just superb.

38422451.review:
Fire Pro Wrestling is a game that until a few minutes before I played it I had never even heard about it.  I was told about the game and told that it was comparable to "WWF No Mercy" for the Nintendo 64.  While that is probably the best way to describe it to someone, it's so much more than that.

The game is just very smooth, the grappling feels totally worse than No Mercy until you get used to it and realize they made the small change for a reason.  The matches really feel like real wrestling matches, the game encourages it by allowing the build up moves to work more often in the beginning and you have to work you way up your finisher.  No more body slam over and over and spam taunt until your opponent gets up then fininsher, rinse repeat that you see so much in No Mercy.  

The AI is really cool as well,  I've seen matches with characters based on wrestlers from WWE that were shockingly close to something you would actually see them do.

The shining moment in this game is the customization of the wrestlers, ring apron and arena as well as referees.  You can find almost anyone (or anything) in the workshop and some of the detail put into these wrestlers is insane.  The moment I downloaded Kenny Omega and realized someone actually went through the time to map out the "One Winged Angel" was insane.  I never thought I was see this in a wrestling game and if I did assumed it would be more new style wrestling game which I don't care for at all.

This game is fantastic and if you don't buy it very soon you're going to end up paying more for it because this baby is coming out of early access!  I think I paid like $20 and right now it's sitting at $13.39 which is a steal since the price is going up to $25 for realease I believe.  At any of these price points I think it's a good buy.

38421293.review:
For my money, this is the greatest game ever made.  It certainly is my favorite by a mile. That said, it takes a certain type of person to get into this game. If you are not very creative or have a poor imagination, you may not like this game or even know what the hell to do with it. But if you enjoy creating and crafting and making something your own, and are a wrestling fan to any degree, this is the game for you. 

My version of Fire Pro looks different from anyone else's in the world. Every character is my own creation, even the referees; every ring mat and apron I designed myself; every theme song that plays, every move and grunt and groan and taunt a wrestler makes, I hand picked it myself. There is no story mode being force fed to you by the developers; it is a pure professional wrestling sandbox of endless possibilities. More than any other game, Fire Pro has let me create my own world, my own universe. When I fire up the game, I'm off to another dimension entirely. 

I think the 430+ hours I've played in Early Access says it all. I adore this game. If you are an intelligent, patient, creative, and perhaps a bit odd and quirky individual with a penchant for pro wrestling, your search has ended. Look no further. This is your game.

38408573.review:
[b] - Hidden Gem inside! -[/b]
Nach 12 Jahren (seit FPR) und vielen Jahren warten auf ein neuen Teil, hat Spike nun endlich die logische Weiterentwicklung fortgesetzt und genau einen perfekten Moment abgepasst.
Fast ein halbes Jahr im Early Access. Somit kann ich nach einigen Spielstunden doch schon ein Fazit ziehen.

Ich bin intensiver Fire Pro Spieler seit Fire Pro G (vorher schon auf SNES gespielt, aber nicht so viel wie die folge Teile.) Returns für die PS2 war damals über Jahre hinweg natürlich das non-plus ultra was Wrestlinggames zu bieten hatte. Es hat bis auf die Grafik selbst das "Flagschiff" WWE 2k in den Schatten gestellt. 
Nun ist es einfacher als noch vor einigen Jahren an die Fire Pro Spiele zu kommen. (Kein Import nötig)
Somit sollte man sich einfach drauf einlassen. (nicht vom äußeren Look abschrecken lassen, es bietet so viel mehr!)

Wie schon immer bietet Fire Pro eine unzählige Menge an Erstellmöglichkeiten (Matchvariationen, Wrestler, Moveset, Entrance, Referee, Arena, Belts, Ligen / Teams)

Dank Workshop ist es nun auch möglich Wrestler, Arenen Texturen, Referees etc. mit 1 Klick ins Spiel zu integrieren. Und das solange bis der Speicher der Festplatte voll ist! Da dies nur wenige kb klein sind, ist es möglich nahezu unbegrenzt alles runterzuladen. Egal ob WWE, ECW, WCW, ROH, Japan, Lucha .... Selbst Serien, Film Figuren etc für alle ist etwas dabei, da die Community sehr stark ist & viele Leute auch der FPR Ära zu FPWW wechselten & den ganzen sich anschlossen. Mittlerweile gibt es so viele gute Creator, die einfach alles perfekt nachbauen. 
JEDER Wrestler kann bis zu 4 Attires im Spiel haben (auch das ist neu)

Selbst die Logik ist bei JEDEM Wrestler sehr genau einstellbar. Wie reagiert Wrestler X auf den Move, wie schlau er ist etc. auch bei dem Gegner ist dies wirksam!
Entrance ist mit eigenen mp3 import auch gegeben, somit wirkt das ganze noch stimmiger. (Entrance edit wird wohl noch ausgebaut, auch nötig, da es ein wenig limitiert ist)
- Movesets sind auch bis auf das kleinste gut einstellbar und dank dem Umfang ist es fast unmöglich Moves nicht zu finden, die es nicht im Spiel gibt. (Zudem werden kostenlos auch mehr nachgeliefert via Patches)

Arena Edit etc ist super. Ring, belt Edit ist noch stark limitiert, dies wird noch ausgebaut und sollte auch. Da diese bisher nur nach no-product aussieht. Aber immerhin gibt es eine Möglichkeit, zudem eine Option für die Zukunft.

KI / Matchablauf
Die KI ist wie gesagt extrem schlau! 
Man kann Matches simulieren (CPU vs CPU), diese machen allein beim zuschauen Spaß! Das schafft sonst auch keins! Auch im Match reagieren und agieren die Wrestler stets gut oder deren selbst eingestellte KI entsprechend.
Somit spielt sich auch JEDES Match komplett anders, mir machen allein die singles Matches so viel Spaß, da diese immer wieder neue Aktionen, Highlights und Herangehensweise erfordern oder bieten. 
So kann man auch ein Gegner dominieren, im re-match aber komplett ablosen. Da es nie nach dem gleichen Schema abläuft.
Insgesamt gibt es 10 Stufen an Schwierigkeitsgraden des Gegners. Hier agieren sie einfach noch schlauer, je höher man das Level stellt. Es gibt kein "schwerer = sinnloses bzw unrealistisches kontern wie z.b. in den WWE Spielen.
Auch im Match könnte man theoretisch gleich einen finishing Move ansetzen, da man jeder Zeit wie auch "in echt" alles ansetzen könnte. Meistens ist der Gegner noch zu fit. Man muss eine Kette mit low-mid-strong moves aufbauen. Das macht es sehr taktischer und anspruchsvoller 

Matcharten:
Es ist möglich alles zu kombinieren. Von normalen, zu TT, Cage, Royal Rumble, Deathmatches (auch dies ist möglich, barbed wire (ropes), lighttubes, etc sind auch möglich. Im Menü sieht es nach wenig Matcharten aus, allerdings gibt es im Folgemenü eine Option bei der man alles variieren & kombinieren kann. Z.b. Steht nirgendwo das man ein Triple Threat Match hat, dies kann man dennoch einstellen. Oder 8 Man Tags (offline bis zu 8 Spieler!) mit Elimination + barbed wire etc.) Es gibt unbegrenzt Möglichkeiten und hoffentlich auch noch mehr, so das alles abgedeckt wird. Die wichtigsten sowie, Deathmatches, und viele mehr sind abgedeckt. Tuniermodus ala King of the Ring etc auch enthalten.
Selbst ein MMA Modus gibt es!! In einen Wrestlingspiel!! oder auch Shootfight Matches usw.

StoryMode? / GM Mode?
Es gibt aktuell nicht wie in FPR einen Story Mode, sondern einen Aufgaben Modus in dem Man 50 unterschiedliche Aufgaben machen muss um auch Moves etc freizuschalten.
Dies bietet Spaß, teils sind sie knackig schwer, aber dennoch sehr kurzweilig. Der Hauptteil aktuell liegt auf Exhibition und Online Mode (4 Spielern gleichzeitig aktuell!)
Demnächst folgt aber eine Art GM Mode so kann man sich da als Big Boss austoben und vergleichlich wie in WWE Spielen sein Wrestlinguniversum pflegen. 

Animationen / Grafik / Technik:
Wie gesagt gibt es dank der 2D / 2.5D Sprites eine extrem große Anzahl an Moves und verdammt gut aussehende Konter!
Es ist nahezumöglich aus fast jeder Lage zu kontern und gekontert zu werden, diese sind auch meistens eine Augenweide.
- Blut ist auch verdammt gut in Szene gesetzt! 
- Soundtrack FPW typisch und noch besser als FPR.

Zur Grafik hat sich seit FPR logischerweise sehr viel getan, es ist immer noch der zeitlose 2D Stil, von dem man sich nicht abschrecken lassen sollte, es wirkt alles noch schärfer, die Modelle wirken noch besser und grafisch ist es dank 1920 x 1080+ eine sehr gute Auflösung. Auch die Frauen Edits, haben sich seit dem letzten sehr gut verändert und wirken nun auch wie ein guter Teil des Spiels und nicht wie ein Bonus, die aber nie wirklich zuerkennen sind. Gerade bei nachgebauten Wrestlerinnen.

Bevor man tausende von Wrestlern / Chars. runterlädt würde ich empfehlen die Cache zu aktivieren, somit läuft es bei der Auswahl noch flüssiger und es lädt im Spiel alles besser nach, incl. läuft das Spiel noch sauberer. Cache nach vielen Download aktivieren kann beim ersten Start etwas Zeit beanspruchen.

FAZIT:
Es ist zeitlos und wenn es ständig mit Updates versorgt wird, brauch man die evtl die nächsten 10 Jahre oder noch mehr kein anderes Wrestlingspiel mehr.
Es gibt noch viele Punke, die Spike verbessern kann und auch wird. Da die Community seeehr stark mit eingebunden wird, lesen die Devs. auch öfters mal in den Foren, da sie genau wissen wie gut es läuft oder auch seit FPR regelrecht explodiert vor Edits, Ideen & treue Fans die das gerne unterstützen, da sie merken das Spike einfach über Jahre ein unglaublich gutes Produkt bietet. (Für langfristige Sicht)
Mir persönlich fehlen auch noch so kleine Dinge oder auch "größere" trotz Japan Stil, würde ich auch gern westliche Matcharten ala Tables oder Ladder Varianten sehen. Vllt auch mal Backstage brawls und nicht "nur auf Rampe etc. oder Kleine optimier Dinge, die noch nicht perfekt sind.
Dennoch ist es mit dem aktuellen Stand ein hochwertiges Spiel, was dem Preis absolut gerecht wird!
Ich bin NIE Vollpreis Käufer gerade im AAA Bereich, außer bei Indietiteln die es verdient haben. Und als Day 1 Käufer für 19.99€ war es JEDEN Cent wert.
Da es das Grüst von FPR stets und ständig verbessert und in vielen Dingen überholt hat und sich ständig extrem von Update zu Update verbessert. Spike bringt immer als nur Bugfixes in den Patches mitsich und ständig wird wie gesagt auch sehr schnell auf die Community reagiert.
+ guter Mod support
An alle die sich unschlüssig sind:
Wagt den Schritt, gerade jetzt im Sale (13.39€) ist eine gute Investition, wenn ihr auf der Suche nach geilen Wrestling / Fighting Spielen seid!
Die Grafik ist nicht massentauglich, dennoch ist der Kern pures gold, Das Gameplay! + Edit Möglichkeiten.
Also überwindet euch, ich habe evtl. jetzt einiges vergessen, aber ich beantworte gerne Fragen hier unter dem Review, wenn ich etwas vergessen habe. Da dies bei so viel tollen echt mal unter geht. (Incl. Zeichenbegrenzung. :D)

DANKE an Spike, die es endlich auch auf PC gebracht haben! <3

A versão definitiva do jogo de luta livre definitivo, feito por fãs, para fãs, com constante feedback dos jogadores e aperfeiçoando tudo que o resto da série trouxe de bom.

Vejo muitas opiniões tratando o jogo como uma "alternativa barata" e "para PCs ruins" de WWE 2K, o que é uma comparação ridícula, este jogo tem um propósito totalmente diferente e visa um nicho diferente de fã de luta livre, que busca uma real experiência de simulação ao inves de algo apenas agradável aos olhos.

Fire Pro World is the last wrestling game anyone will ever need.
Building a dream roster from just workshop creations alone is fantastic, and thanks to CPU logic settings, everyone fights more or less how you would expect them to.
Learning how to create your own characters can be a bit of a challenge for newcomers, both sprite editing and logic settings take a while to really get down but its extremely rewarding once you figure it out.

38393507.review:
I bought this on a whim, having never played any wrestling games. What I got was the most fun I've had in a long time, and after playing through the tutorial and a few missions I was kicking AI's a** with the coolest wrestling moves ever. 

The best thing about this game is that every single combination of direction+attack seems to do something at any given point, so there's no need to learn complicated combos like in fighting games. The thing that makes the fights challenging is getting the timing of inputs right, however it's very intuitive and I got a hang of it after less than an hour. The game also lacks hud, which at first surprised me, but in the end it just helped me focus on the visual spectacle instead of arbitrary numbers and status bars. 

Overall, best fighting-ish game I've ever played and most fun I've had in a long long time. And I don't even like pro wrestling that much.

Com a integração com o steam workshop, você pode criar um personagem, arena ou referee e compartilhar facilmente com o mundo. Da mesma forma, você pode facilmente baixar conteúdo da workshop para integrar ao seu jogo.

O sistema de criação de personagens é robusto e permite você configurar além do visual e moveset, a lógica do personagem (indicando como ele se comporta durante as partidas). O sistema permite também editar wrestlers baixados na workshop caso você queira fazer alguma alteração.

Além de todo o conteúdo de wrestling, FPWW inclui também modalidades de MMA (conhecida no jogo como "Cement Style), desde o octógono do UFC (que no caso do jogo é um decágono) ou shoot-wrestling (PANCRASE).

37609196.review:
A true Fire Pro Wrestling game has arrived, and it's on Steam!  The game itself is better than Fire Pro Wrestling Returns, with many improvements and bug fixes compared to Returns, and the game is still in early access.

Even better, the developers are listening to suggestions and adding things in.  An example was the S-1 Kickboxing rules match that was taken out of the game from Fire Pro Wrestling Returns.  When the community asked for it to come back, the developers added it.

Another great thing Fire Pro Wrestling World added was Steam Workshop support.  Now you can just download a created wrestler instead of having to create one from a template.  The workshop also adds custom ring mats, aprons, turnbuckles, and even ring posts.

Finally, the game runs great, even on low end and old computers.  itachi4937, known on YouTube for creating WWE2K CAWs, tested the game on an old Core i3-2330M with Intel integrated graphics, and 4 GB of RAM.  The game kept a constant 60 FPS, even during an 8 Man Battle Royale in a exploding barbwire match!

I highly recommend this for not just Fire Pro Wrestling fans, but fans of wrestling games in general.  You won't find a better wrestling game on Steam, including the WWE games.

新ハードが出るたびに「ファイプロが出たら買う」と豪語していたファイプロ好きなら迷わず買うべきです。
アーリーアクセスのため不便な点や不具合も散見されまだまだ発展途上中ですが、かなりの頻度でアップデートされています。

レスラーをエディットして、ロジックを作り込んで、観戦して、動きのおかしいところを直して、また観戦して…を繰り返しているといつの間にか時間が経っている…

37565495.review:
Fire Pro Wrestling World is a game I was looking forward to ever since it was announced. When I first played it, I was not disappointed. The Fire Pro series has a long and storied history, but the fraction of American releases is only the tip of the iceberg so to speak. If you’re familiar with the series, you’ll probably know exactly what to expect. It picks up right where the last game left off. It adds a bunch of new features with more on the way. The added Steam Workshop feature is a godsend for downloading CAWs if you’re familiar with the pains of the older techniques for Fire Pro Returns. For those of you who’ve never played a Fire Pro game, it’s vastly different from your average 2k wrestling game. The most startling difference is the use of sprites for the wrestlers instead of 3d models, but this limitation turns out to be very helpful in the creation of convincing real life wrestlers. The controls are a bit hard to wrap your head around at first, but they get easier once you learn how to time your attacks. I recommend looking at a guide if you have trouble understanding the grapple system. The customization is where the game really shines. You can find pretty much any wrestler you could imagine on the Steam Workshop.  A vast amount of CAW parts allows for near endless amounts of potential creations. There are also a large variety of moves that can allow for various wrestlers’ move sets to be accurately represented. You can also name finishers, which is a feature I sorely miss from the WWE SvR series. The ability to tweak logic allows for wrestlers to play out nearly exactly like their real life counterparts. This makes the game a wonderful simulator for wrestling matches. The customization for rings also allows for a decent chunk of real life wrestling shows to be accurately represented. The only thing lacking customization as of right now are the title belts, which are the same models from over a decade ago. (Hopefully this gets changed during development as it’s still early access.) There are also a variety of different match types that allow for some really fun moments. From exploding barbwire deathmatches, to MMA cage fights, there is a lot of variety in the match types. You can have up to 8-man matches. (No 30-man royal rumble matches as of right now) The only match types you’ll really miss are WWE style matches like Hell in a Cell or ladder matches. This is due to the game being heavily Japanese Puroresu oriented. While the game has modes like tournaments and leagues, right now it is missing a proper GM style mode and career mode, both of which were in previous games. I have hopes that this will get added later as it’s still in early access. There’s also an online mode that is pretty fun, but I haven’t played much of it.

Here's a list of the pros and cons for me.

Pros:
Loads and loads of customization
Sprite based characters (Either a pro or con depending on your tastes)
Fun gameplay (Especially the deathmatches!)
Extremely accurate simulation
Lots of variety in match types (MMA, boxing, etc.)
Steam Workshop implementation is great
Closest thing we’ll ever get to a new NJPW/AJPW game

Cons:
Sprite based characters (Either a pro or con depending on your tastes)
Control scheme is a little difficult to learn (It’s easy once you get the hang of it though)
No WWE style special matches
No career or GM mode (At this point in early access)

Fire Pro Wrestling World is a game that I love, and I’d thoroughly recommend it if you like: old school wrestling games, simulating matches, Japanese Puroresu, and/or four-way exploding barbwire deathmatches between Duke Nukem, Kurt Cobain, Danny Devito, and Hatsune Miku.

37534153.review:
For years and years, people have asked for a successor to No Mercy on the N64. Finally we have it, though it'd be understandable if you didn't notice since it isn't polygonal (no big deal, the graphics from that era are the thing that have aged the worst anyway). 

While Fire Pro Wrestling World doesn't come fully formed out of the (metaphorical) box, one trip to the Community Workshop will show you that if you can imagine a wrestler, there is probably someone out there who has made them. Doink? Mantour? Vince McMahon? The only limitation is someone's imagination. 

And since you can also code the wrestlers' AI, a well-made character will honestly feel like the real thing. Wrestling Brock Lesnar feels completely different from wrestling Psycosis -- as it should. 

Above all else, Fire Pro Wrestling World is a joy to play. A well-made character is fun to use in ways that a WWE licensed game hasn't figured out in almost 20 years. Throw 2K in the trash and give this a chance. You won't be disappointed.

While there are some features and nuances I miss from previous entries in the franchise, the ease of online content sharing alone makes this the best franchise entry so far.  To give more context, while the gameplay is excellent, many view Fire Pro Wrestling as a tool more than a game. Simulating matches, running e-feds, and constantly tinkering with AI behavior are all community staples. As per the usual, it's not exactly novice-friendly, although the inclusion of a tutorial helps. Fire Pro's controls and myriad gameplay systems are deeply satisfying when you come to grips with them. Although not as input-intensive, as say a fighting game, there's a lot to take in and understand from both a gameplay strategy and content creation perspective. Although, for some, the mere spectacle of how capable/versatile the CPU wrestlers are is enough.

36969917.review:
I discovered the Fire Pro series through the magic of SNES emulation and Super Fire Pro Wrestling X Premium. At a time when even the best wrestling games available were barely playable, it was a shockingly fun, fluid representation of a sport that barely makes sense on its own. It was customizable as hell, it was ocean-deep and it was rife with the incredible joys of copyright infringement, as Not The Undertaker fought Not Kenta Kobashi in Definitely Not AJPW.

It was built for the Steam modding environment two decades before the environment existed. It's such a natural fit for the kind of fun stupidity modders make that it's incredible to think it wasn't designed with it in mind. It is a game where strict wrestling simulations, MMA leagues, celebrity deathmatches and VGCW revivals are all equally likely and equally fun.

36953705.review: In my opinion this could possibly be the best wrestling simulation video game of all time, once it's completed that is.  An incredibly deep roster and edit feature that makes your roster virtually limitless.  The gameplay is tremendous and is the ONLY video game that has ever re-created the feeling of a real wrasslin' match in my opinion.  You'll be sweating bullets in your living room when involved in a thirty minute classic with back and forth near falls, highspots and surprise comebacks. Surprisingly, one of the most enjoyable features in this game is simulating matches. You play the role of a wrestling federation general manager and create a dream card, then sit back and watch the matches unfold.  If you've never played a Fire Pro wrestling game before, and want a wrestling game that actually feels like a wrestling game, then give this one a try.  There's wrestling games, and then there's wrestling games.  This one leans heavily towards the latter.

36576384.review:
have no idea where to start. I grew up loving wrestling, like all of us I'm sure. My cousin and I played a TON of WWF Royal Rumble and RAW on snes. We had a whiteboard we bought and laminated wrestlers that we moved around to make cards, and show champs etc. It was impressive considering I was like 7. Well some time passed, and in 1996 he graduated from high school and joined the Navy. We stayed in touch, and talked about wrestling a lot. He got stationed in Japan and started telling me about this game called Fire Pro Wrestling. So the legend was growing in my head, and as an idiot kid I wasn't too sure how to find things online yet. I used webcrawler and finally found Gamefaqs. Saw the SNES stuff, and begged my mom to buy it for me. Never happened.

1997 for my birthday, all I wanted was a Japanese Saturn and Six Man Scramble. Well this didn't happen either. So all this time I am still corresponding with my cousin. He's telling me all about 6MS in letters, and I am just beyond jealous. I get Warzone and Nitro, but the itch is there. Revenge, and World Tour are helping ease me out of the wanting Fire Pro so bad. 

Fast forward to 1999. I read online, probably Gamefaqs, that a new Fire Pro is coming out for playstation. So I knew my cousin was coming home soon, so I just waited for him to talk to him about it. He comes home and I ask him how I get a jp playstation. He introduces me to modchips, and even shows me the action replay method that some people on his base use. So it's set, I am getting this game no matter what I have to do. I am 12 at this point, and living in the middle of nowhere deep south I score a job that summer on a farm. My mom gave my cousin money for the game when he goes back to Japan, and to just ship it to us whenever it comes out. So I know I have a few months before if shows up. I work my ass off all summer to get a Playstation, and I actually had enough saved up by end of July to get the dreamcast at launch. Somewhere end of June I buy my Playstation with Tekken 3, Silent Hill, an Action Replay, and Harvest Moon (and maybe NBA Live 98 for real cheap, can't remember.)

Anyway the game comes somewhere around mid to end July and I have no IDEA what I am doing. I get on gamefaqs, start printing stuff. Reading all of it through, start to kind of understand, but I am still confused. I made some edits, THEY WERE AWFUL, and mostly just played the game. I should go back to that game and try it again.

When D came out, I was older and wiser. Ready to tackle it from every angle. I was a lurker on FPC, never posted until R came out. Followed all the breakthroughs JB was making, and had 6 VMUs and knew what I was doing. I had a blast, introduced my best friend to the series with D. We had been wrestling buddies since 6th grade, and if you remember on the FPC person pack Adam and Lee as The Wacky Deli that's us. And we just went from there. He's the best KOC player I know. He's into the strong style, and I am more into the Dragon Gate lucharesu style. Good friendship, and we still play anytime we get together, which is super hard considering we live in different states. 

This continued with Fire Pro R, and with World it is no different.  This is the game I always dreamed of when I was playing 20 years ago.  This is the series I love, but with a family and a full time job it makes playing a little harder.  I play when I can, and I still enjoy every minute of this game.  I look forward to playing this game when it is out of early access, for a full review of the 1.0 of the game, but for now enjoy the ride!

36355113.review:
Eins der besten Wrestlingspiele der letzten Jahre und sehr viel besser als die letzten WWE 2k Spiele.

Vorallem postiv anzumerken ist das dieses Spiel fast keine Bugs besitzt. Zumindest sind mir keine bekannt oder aufgefallen, obwohl das Spiel bisher nur im Early-Access ist. Sollte eines Tages noch ein Karriere, Story Designer oder gar GM-Mode nachgereicht werden, wäre das einfach nur fantastisch und würde das Spiel noch besser machen. 

Obwohl das Spiel nur in 2d Dargestellt wird, ist  es selbst in der heutigen Zeit sehr schön anzusehen. 

Die Auswahlmöglichkeiten der Wrestler sind gigantisch und es lassen sich problemlos Wrestler aus dem Workshop installieren. So kann man sich ein riesen Roster aus WWF/E, WCW, TNA-Wrestlern, MMA, Boxern usw. kreieren.
Mittlerweile ist auch die Möglichkeit dazugekommen seinen Ring mit echten Logos zu gestalten. So kann man in echten Ringen aus allen möglichen Wrestling, Boxen oder MMA Ringen ein Match austragen.

Hier die Pros:
+ freigestaltbares Roster 
+ sehr guter und starker Workshop
+ sehr guter Editor (Wrestler, Schiri, Ring lassen sich editieren)
+ eigenes und realistisches Verhalten der einzelnen Kämpfer
+ Wrestling + MMA + Boxen im einem Spiel
+ schöne Grafik
+ guter Sound
+ Ring lässt sich mittlerweile frei bearbeiten
+ echte Wrestlingthemes lassen sich bei eigenen Kämpfern hinzufügen
+ intelligente K.I in 10 Schwierigkeitsstufen

Contras:
- bisher gibt es keine Möglichkeit Kämpfer aus dem Workshop eine  Theme zuordnen, wenn nicht vorgegeben.
- bisher keine Laddermatches und Tablematches und kein Royal Rumble
- bisher noch kein Karriere. Story Designer oder GM Mode


Neutral: 
+- teilweise anfangs frustierende Steuerung... ...welche aber nach einer Zeit doch leicht von der Hand geht.

Fazit: Was soll ich sagen? Es ist wirklich schön zu sehen das es noch Entwickler gibt die es mit ihrem Spiel ernst meinen. Die Entwickler von FPW World zeigen dies. Die Möglichkeiten unbegrenzt Wrestler aus allmöglichen Ligen der Welt in ein Spiel zu bekommen ist einfach fantastisch. Ist zwar für FPW-Fans nichts neues, aber Neulingen wie mir in dieser Reihe ist dass ganz einfach eine fantastische Funktion, vorallem durch den Steamworkshop sehr gut gelöst.

35687828.review:
Essentially a massively enhanced, updated version of the previous game in this series, Fire Pro Wrestling Returns (PS2), a game that I also sunk many, many hours into. Whilst a hardcore wrestling fan will probably get the most out of this game, I would recommend it to anyone who has even a passing knowledge of pro wrestling. This is the best Wrestling simulation game out there, bar none. Hell, it's not a bad MMA game either! 

Pros:
-Massive amount of customization, including referee creation, ring creation, the ability to tweak how a wrestler actually wrestles when controlled by the computer etc. 

-Very active fan community who have probably made most wrestlers who have ever lived, and probably a lot of MMA fighters too

-Developers are very in touch with the community and are adding stuff and tweaking stuff very regularly

- Good music

- Detailed sprite work

- Tutorials for a newbie

- Very solid gameplay mechanics in both Wrestling and MMA

- Modes such as Single elimation tournaments, G1 Climax style round Robin leagues, mission mode etc

-Many types of matches, such as Death matches, battle royals, Various MMA match types (UFC, Pancrase/Pride etc) 

Cons:
- Even with tutorials, it can be more difficult for people to get to grips with. 

- Lack of career mode/universe-like mode for a WWE2K fan

-  Relatively bare bones. If you want to book shows, it's more on you to set it up as it doesn't really have a dedicated booking mode as of when i wrote this review

- EA UFC 2 is better for pure MMA gameplay

35451248.review:
I had a brief introduction to the Fire Pro universe with Fire Pro Returns on PS3 (brief because my secondhand PS3 broke 2 weeks after I managed to get the game!). I read about the enthusiasm the fans have for this game and as an ex-wrestling nut (I'm slowly getting back into it now via NJPW and the independent circuit) I had to give it a go. 

I give the game a thumbs up because I am an 'old school' wrestling fan and can appreciate the mechanics and uniqueness of the game. People who find aesthetics to be important may be turned off by this game; graphically this game is not based on realism but on some sort of nostalgic, squared circle, fantasy escapism; graphically it hasn't really changed in years. Also, the timing based system gives each match an element of unpredictability which I like ( the last WWE 2K game I played, 2K13,  was too easy and I won whenever I wanted. Perhaps WWE 2K games are more difficult now but winning got boring (even though I would complain if I lost!)). 

Personally, I find FPW to be Pro Evolution Soccer to WWE's FIFA. The fact you can edit the wrestler's tendencies means they can act like their real world counterpart would do, and this makes each wrestler feel like an individual. This is evident as it is very common for players to create 'edits' (or 'CAWs' in WWE2K speak), and watch the PC sim the matches rather than play the matches yourself. When I played WWE 2K, the moves each wrestler had was different but the mindset/ tendencies/ mentality was the same. Much like Pro Evo's Player ID (where every player plays like he would in real life) versus FIFA's dominance with licenses where every team would 'look' like they do in real life, but actually when you play FIFA, every AI controlled team 'plays' exactly the same. Tough to say style over substance as the WWE 2K games can offer things (real WWE roster, Universe mode etc) that FPW doesn't. As a result, FPW suits a person who can get lost in their own imagination and create story lines in their heads, as well as enjoy the community element as you will rely on strangers to create your desired roster for you (or you can create edits yourself).

Please note, FPW is in early access and I can safely say that the monthly updates are great as Spike actually listen to what's being said on the threads/ forums and make adjustments accordingly. They understand that the people who are playing FPW now are, by and large, the same people who were playing FP before, and this makes loyal fans even more loyal. Also, as it is a PC game, mods and all sorts are making their way into the game to make the experience even more immersive. 

If pure aesthetic glitz and glamour is your thing (FIFA's licenses and presentation, for example) is your thing then you may not be convinced by FPW, but if you want a fighting game mechanic that is truly unique, and you consider yourself a long time wrestling fan (I say 'long time' as I assume younger players won't get their heads around the graphics/ mechanics/ easy DIY roster building) and have never played this game before, then I suggest you by it now before the price goes up. Personally, I think the game will get better as time goes on (at the time of writing they have just released another patch with new arenas) and FPW should be considered a rite of passage for any gaming wrestling fan.

Серия Fire Pro Wrestling — лучшая среди всех реслинг-симуляторов. Никакой мишуры, никаких файтинговых элементов вроде полосок жизни, полосок суперудара и прочего экшн-мусора. Только тонкая психология настоящего реслинга (остальные стили я все же воспринимаю как эддон). Переиздание старой игры всегда чревато отсталостью в плане современных условий геймплея, отчего зачастую кажется скучнее своих современников.  Но геймплей Fire Pro ещё никому не удалось переплюнуть, хотя многие из инди-издателей (фанатов Fire Pro соответственно) шли по этому пути.
Главный, жирный и бескомпромиссный минус переиздания в том, что режима карьеры в этой игре нет. На PS и Dreamcast режима тоже толком не было, если не считать однообразную лестницу из бойцов, которых ты должен победить один за другим. На Gameboy попытки были, в Fire Pro 2 G в карьере открывались новые бойцы, а в финале в качестве награды всех ждал бонус в виде нового режима тайм батл рояль. Этот минус может перечеркнуть все ваше желание играть. 
В итоге из плюсов :
+ геймплей (очень комплексный плюс, в котором занято еще много плюсов)
+ редактор (самый мощный из всех серий реслинг-игр)
Из минусов : 
- нет режима карьеры
- графика (опять же для нового игрока она покажется неоправданно простой)

34863533.review:
While nothing will ever replace the AKI wrestling games of the 90s, this game comes pretty close to what wrestling fans have dreamed of for years and years. You can literally make any wrestler you want. Want Hulk Hogan in his 80s prime? You can do that. Want Stone Cold Steve Austin to wrestle CM Punk? You can do that. Want to sim the G1 Climax with wrestlers from all over the world? You can do that. If you think it, you can do it. 

As far as gameplay goes, it is the deepest of any wrestling game ever made. The combat system is timing based and must be clear and consise. Just like a typical wrestling match, you start with weaker strikes and moves and move your way up the chain as you wear down your opponent. It's the most dynamic wrestling game I have ever played.

If you're a wrestling fan looking for a deeper gaming experience than the WWE 2K games, this one is for you. You won't regret it. Highly recommended!

34651867.review:
If you weren’t ready to rumble, now would be the perfect time. Fire Pro Wrestling World is the latest installment of the beloved Japanese pro wrestling series which also marks its first appearance on the PC. Old school fans will remember fumbling through complicated menus and memorizing a handful of Hiragana letters in order to play. Not anymore! This groundbreaking grappler has never been more accessible and the addition of the Steam Workshop means it’s never been easier to fight your wildest dreams to the death.

The formula hasn’t changed much, but it didn’t have to. Take your surprisingly-detailed 2D combatant into the 3D squared circle and wreak havoc. A new tutorial mode exists to make things easier on rookies, but everything is as straight-forward as ever. Only a jabroni would even consider button mashing. Fire Pro has always been about perfectly timing your moves and balancing your stamina en route to a flawless victory. Tag teams, steel cages, barbed wire, battles royal, landmines, kickboxing, MMA rules, or just plain old fashioned pro wrestling are just a few of the options available to you. Outside of the fighting, Fire Pro has always been about customization. Design your own refs, rings, belts, movesets, and, of course, wrestlers, with an easy-to-use editor featuring an impossible number of combinations. It’s the only wrestling game you’ll ever need and arguably the only one that ever needed to be made. Fight!

34603212.review:
THE DEFINITIVE pro-wrestling game. Fire Pro Wrestling World iterates on past titles, adding a slew of new match types, moves, customization options, easy modding, and online multiplayer for the first time ever. 

Unlike other wrestling games which operate on stamina and special move gauges, Fire Pro allows its players complete freedom in how a wrestling match is played out. On the one hand, it boasts solid striking and a deep pacing system where early on small moves soften the opponent up for big moves. This makes matches feel tight and competitive, while still feeling like a pro-wrestling match (as opposed to a fighting game). On the other, players are also free to allow their wrestler to take big moves early, to heighten the drama or create a squash match. Also available are MMA (both ring and octagon), boxing, K1, and deathmatches (both barbed wire and explosive), tournaments, and league play. 

Thanks to Steam Workshop integration, you don't have to dive into the somewhat-tedious character creator, and your active rosters can be as varied as you wish. At the time of writing, my personal subsribtion count sits at almost 750 wrestlers-- spanning many eras and promotions of actual pro-wrestling, to TV, anime, games, books, and movies. If you've ever wanted to see Trump get a fork jammed in his forehead by an angry Homer Simpson, for example, you can absolutely get that done in this game. Factions, stables, promotions, and the like are easy to set up and transfer wrestlers into. You can even set whether a particular group is loved or jeered by the crowds.

Also exciting is the devs' embrace of the modding community. Many mod-packs exist (some even stickied on the steam discussion board by the developers), allowing for basic things like ring textures all the way to rule changes or completely new match types (inferno deathmatch! explosive balloon deathmatch! K1 rules!). Mods are exceedingly simple to apply, as well. 

I've yet to play any online matches, so I'll not comment on the netcode other than to say I haven't seen many complaints about it. I will mention that the game supports at least four local players for all your tag-team and fatal four-way needs, and also allows for a mix of player-controlled and AI wrestlers to participate together. 

All in all, Fire Pro Wrestling World understands what pro-wrestling is about: freedom of expression. From the minutae of holding a button to sell a slam long enough for your opponent to climb a turnbuckle and make themselves famous, to the much broader strokes of deciding who you want in your game, in what promotion, in what ring, in what match type, for what belt, FPWW has it all.

34531804.review:
Don't be put off just because "ew it looks like a super nintendo game". If that's your thinking, then the game is too advanced for you. This is a game in which you can not only create Hulk Hogan, but you can fine tune his AI logic to make him act exactly like Hulk Hogan would. Try doing that on that "other" series.

Since everything is sprite based, your created characters will all look like they belong in the same ring together.

The gameplay is simple, but so complex at the same time. You walk around until you knock into each other, at which point the wrestlers will grapple. As soon as the animation finishes, that's when you want to hit your attack buttons. First person to register an attack wins the grapple and gets the move. You have to start with your small grapple moves first! If you try going for your chokeslams and powerbombs right away, you will be reversed out of your boots. You need to start small and build up, like an actual wrestling match.

Strikes are going to be difficult at first if you have not played this series before. You need to get the distance just right. Too close and you will miss the attack. It can be very hard at first: For the PS2 entry in this series, I took it out of the box, played it for an hour getting frustrated at it, powered it off and shoved it in my game storage for a month. Saw it again after that, tried it again, and once I got the striking down and it all clicked, then I started having a lot of fun with it. Don't let the strikes put you off this game like it did me. You can and will learn, and once you do you will be glad you didn't give up.

"Do you recommend this game?" If you are a wrestling fan, I cannot possibly recommend it enough. Give it a try, you might find a whole new world out there that is very different from the WWE universe, and it might be a little scary at first, but we'll all love to help you out on your way to becoming the world champion.

34419985.review:
While there are a few things missing (notably, for me anyways, the mat logo option for rings), you have easily the most customizable wrestling experience on PC even in Early Access. What it lacks in graphics compared to the long running WWE 2K series, it makes up for with sheer options.
But I'd be lying if I said you'd be able to just jump into the game without understanding the controls and gameplay. It's honestly intimidating at first, especially learning how the hitboxes do or do not work. And the customization is also perhaps TOO in depth for the average casual player to jump into immediately, but it grows on you in time. If you're not creative enough, the Workshop has you covered with an insane amount of uploads over a month in.
In short, if you're a wrestling fan, this is the experience you've been waiting for on PC.

-EDIT 11/2/2017-
Ring editing is now in full effect, with entrance music also being added since this review. The ring editing is on par with WWE 2K, as opposed to FPW Returns where it was only a mat logo. This makes faithfully recreating old rings easier than ever. Right now the only thing I feel is missing is champions physically having their belts.
This is still in my honest opinion the best wrestling game on PC.

34333468.review:
Das beste Wrestling Spiel auf dem Markt! Die Fire Pro Serie ist seit dem Jahr 1989 fest in der japanischen Spielekultur verankert, und freut sich ebenfalls äußerste Beliebtheit bei den Fans aus den nordamerikanischen Ländern und auch in Europa. Doch was macht Fire Pro denn wirklich so besonders?

Das [b] Modding![/b]  Die Community der Fire Pro Spiele (dazu gehörig auch die Spin Offs á la King of Colosseum) ist wirklich groß, sehr akribisch am arbeiten und überaus freundlich. Es gibt allerlei Arten von Wrestlern zu finden, Ringe, Championship Gürtel und und und. Bei diesem Spiel, also Fire Pro Wrestling World, findet man im Steam Workshop nun weitaus mehr als 10000 Edits zum runterladen. Custom Rings, Belts werden noch in Folge reingepatcht (das Spiel ist im EA). Man hat wirklich so viele Möglichkeiten im Editierbereich, dass man einen Jushin Thunder Liger genauso echt aussehen lassen kann, wie Hulk Hogan oder sogar fiktive Charaktere wie Akuma von Street Fighter. Zudem hat der Workshop die lästigen "Packs" abgeschafft und mit dem "Kollektion" Button, kann man auch die komplette ECW aus den 90er Jahren runterladen mit paar Klicks.

Ebenfalls ein großes Plus ist die [b] Simulation[/b] . Kein Wrestling Spiel lässt zwei CPUs so realistisch gegeneinander kämpfen wie diese, dafür ist im Editier Bereich die Logic "schuld". Erfahrene Fire Pro Spieler wissen ganz genau wie man einen Charakter realistisch nach baut, sodass man das Gefühl hat man schaut wirklich ein echtes Wrestlingmatch. Es gibt Menschen, inklusive mir, die noch nie (!) ein einziges Match selber gespielt haben, und ich bin bspw. seit 2005 "dabei".

Wenn man selber spielen will, dann muss man Mumm haben. Das Ding ist nicht einfach zu spielen, es ist nach dem typisch japanischen Stil gerichtet mit den Grapple Buttons. Jede Taste hat seinen Hintergrund, wenn man vor einem Gegner steht dann ist man im Front Grapple Mode. Stehst du hinter einem? Back Grapple, usw. Es ist kein Button smashing angesagt, sondern Timing ist das A und O. Seid auf jeden Fall geduldig!

Die Grafik ist in 2D gehalten, was vielleicht direkt viele abschrecken wird im Jahre 2017, aber es ist eben das klassische Fire Pro, welches sich gegen die 3D Version King of Colosseum durchgesetzt hat. 

[b] Kurzum:[b]  Fire Pro ist was für Wrestling und MMA Fans, welche es gerne realistisch und anspruchsvoll mögen. Der Editierbereich ist unfassbar riesig, mit dem Patch von heute sind sogar MP3 Entrance Themes erlaubt, welche man seinen Charakteren zuschustern kann. Für 19,99 kann man hier nun wirklich nichts falsch machen und spätestens wenn man das Ding gecheckt hat, ist man gehooked!

34171353.review:
過去シリーズからのファイプロファンにはおすすめしますが、これが最初という方には現状の完成度ではおすすめできません。アーリーアクセス版ならではの楽しみ方ができる人向けです。

アーリーアクセス版ですので、快適に遊べる状態にはありません。また、シリーズ集大成と呼べるほどにはボリュームアップしたわけでもありません。12年間の空白期間による過剰な期待や過去作への思い出補正もあって、現状ではDやZやリターンズよりも劣化したようにすら感じられます。

これからに期待しつつ、バージョン 0.9005 現在での辛口レビューです。

■良い点
・グラフィックが向上し、エディットの自由度が高くなった
・打撃応酬、掟破り、カスタムサウンドトラック等の新機能
・活躍中のレスラーの新技が追加され、今後にも期待できる
・エディットレスラーをアップロード／ダウンロードできる
・MODによりリングエディットや細かいルール変更ができる
・完成版へ向けての開発過程に意見やデバッグで参加できる
・フォーラム、某巨大掲示板、twitch等での意見交換が熱い

■不満点
・チープな見た目のUIと、全般にゲームニクスに欠けている
・アップデート毎に、新規部分に動作不具合が多数見つかる
・技表記の不統一やカテゴリー間違い等、稚拙なミスが多数
・若干改善されたが、エディットの操作性のヒドさは致命的
・シナリオや団体運営などの新モードは、現時点では未実装
・過去シリーズ時点から追加要望が出続けている技が未実装
・普通にあると思われるエディットパーツがなく、中途半端
・オンラインはタイムラグで普通に遊べず、閑散としている
・カスタムサウンドトラックは説明不足な上、不具合が多い
・ワークショップのアイテム分類タグが少ないなど、不親切

34140837.review:
I haven't played the Fire Pro Wrestling series before, so this was my first contact with it. And I don't think I quite got it.

The artstyle is really not to my taste. Obviously, though, this varies from person to person and anyone can judge what they think about it by looking at screenshots or videos. The sound is quite awful, however: I have a hard time imagining that anyone fully enjoys it.

One good thing about the artstyle is that it allows for easily creation of hundred of assets, allowing for ample graphical customization, which seems to be a big draw for this community. There's also an ample library of wrestling moves, and customizing movesets seems like it could be fun (if the interface was less of a chore to navigate, though the devs said they are working on that).

But it all falls apart for me when it actually matters the most: the actual game. There really isn't much of a game around the pieces you create.

The wrestling gameplay is too simplistic, the hit detection feels terrible, and there doesn't seem to be anything else besides the actual wrestling matches yet. 

Like a number of reviewers noted: this would be a fine $5 game. It doesn't look, sound or play like a $20 game.

I guess that for those that are part of the already estabelished following of Fire Pro Wrestling, this might probably be worth it. For others, I can't really recommend it at this price.

34109824.review:
Where do I begin. Fire Pro Wrestling is a franchise that got it right and kept getting it right all the way to now. Its not even a question. The 2K series is good for visuals but if you want the blood and guts, scientific, technical, and just has the stuff look no further than this. Its a wrestling fan's wrestling game. I can't even begin to start listing the reasons but i'll provide as much as my attention span will let me.

Many of them grew up to become software engineers and ners o plenty. They create the best content any workshop game has ever had. The amount of wrestlers people have made for this game is ongoing. 34026395.review: This is a phenomenal wrestling game, the game play is the tightest of the entire series and the customization is endless. Highly recommended for anybody that enjoys pro wrestling.

34021209.review:
Back in Late 90's/Early 2000's, wrestling games were everywhere, with great titles such as  the Smackdown, the early Smackdown vs Raw, and of course the old Aki wrestling games for the Nintendo 64. We got great wrestling experiences unlike the ones we get today from 2K studios. The wrestling games that 2k makes every year improve few things, and are lacking in features compared to the games from when we were kids. But if there was one game from that old period that stood out from the rest, it was Fire Pro Wrestling Returns (the sequel to the game “Fire Pro Wrestling”). It wasn't like any other game, it had old school 2D graphics, customization for nearly everything, and it had a fantastic grapple system, in short, the game was a masterpiece. The series began in Japan during the late 80’s, and none of the games from the series were sold outside of Japan until 2005. Sadly, this was the last Fire Pro game to be developed for another 10 years. But after waiting for so long, fans of the Fire Pro series are getting the sequel they’ve always wanted.

Well, here it is, Fire Pro Wrestling Word, let’s talk about the customizability. The game is just as customizable as its previous installments, if not better. With the ability to create and edit wrestlers as well as referees, players are sure to love this game, though It is lacking in the amount of clothes you can put on a wrestler. you can create as many wrestlers as you want, as long as you have the space for it. You can also change the settings of matches with things like background music, DQ, count out, etc. The devs have also revealed on Twitter that they are going to allow you to upload custom music to use as wrestler entrance themes, as well as background music. One issue I had with the game was how complicated creating a custom wrestler was. You have to download them from the workshop, and then you have to go to create new wrestler/model wrestler to set them up to a promotion and team. This confused me as I spent multiple hours downloading wrestlers off the workshop only to not no where they were, I had to use google to figure it out.

The grappling in this game is alot different than most wrestling games. The wrestlers grapple by walking into each other, then an animation plays of them locking up, where you need to go through a sort of quick time event in order to do a move. It takes a few hours to get used to it but when you do, It works great. Another Flaw I have is that in order to hit your opponent you have to be a precise distance away from them or it won’t connect.

I must say for an early access game, it’s pretty clean, I have only discovered one real bug. Sometimes when a computer opponent has a weapon, their player model will start to turn in different directions really fast, which always make me dizzy whenever I see it. Overall this is a very high recommend for fans of the wrestling genre. I can’t wait for them to finish it, this could end up being the greatest wrestling game of all time, only time will tell. Finally, I give this game a 7/5 in true Dave Meltzer fashion due to its great customization, unique gameplay, and an affordable price.
